description.en: Part of the course (approx 1/3) is in the form of lectures that give an overview about the topic in general. The lecturers represent different topics and present their own experience in the field. The other part (approx 2/3) is in the form of student presentation / discussion. The presentations / discussions are organized into topics.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to give an overview of the field of nanotechnologies and its applications in medicine. The main focus will be in medical applications of nanomaterials, functionalization of nanomaterials and the output as diagnostic devices, contrast agents and drug delivery vehicles.

learning_outcomes.en: Students have theoretical understanding about different subfields and branches in Nanomedicine. Through seminary discussions the students have an overview of various future directions in nanotechnology research.

independent_work.et:
Homework 1: Presentation
I will start a collection of studies/reports (notable and/or interesting scientific publications), from which everyone can choose
You can make YOUR OWN choice, but you have to get approval from Kaido Kurrikoff, Tarmo Tamm, or Saoni Baneferji first
The study for the oral presentation has to have some impact and has to include some "real" science. As all studies are different we can not make too strict rules about what the study/report must or can not be, but bear in mind that the eval points take various contributions into account: 
The quality of the original study. Do not choose too simple story! It must be a challenge to you and it must include technical things that are new to you, that is the purpose! 
The quality of your own delving into the topic. There is individual work and effort involved. If not all technical aspects of the study are not comprehensible, it is still OK as long as you understand the aim of the method, the purpose of the technique, and can follow (and present) the general idea of the study. 
The presentation itself. A 10(?)-minute oral presentation. This is the medium through which you will demonstrate your effort and contribution, so please prepare. It is a shame if you chose a good story, worked hard to understand complicated methodology and scientific reasoning, only to present it in a way that the audience could not understand your message and see your knowledge. Your fellow students will contribute in giving points for the presentations. 
The "opposition". Each student will oppose one presenter. This means that you will read the story carefully before the presentation, you'll have the first chance to ask questions. the idea is not strictly "opposing", it can be a debate or discussion, clarification etc. The opponent will also get points for the effort!
Each of you will propose a question, which MAY be chosen to be a part of the final test, provided that the question is good! If this is the case, you'll probably know the answer to one of the questions in the exam!

Homework 2: Report
Can be a group work (max 2 persons), in this case, the topics must align - you have to present a single report that has one beginning and one ending, i.e. one whole story
It is recommended that the report is based on the publication that you have already worked through and in the same topic. However, your written report must expand on this (use your creativity) - you can, for example, present a written analysis on a topic that has been the subject of the lectures. You have to use and go through additional sources of information. In this case, the source can be broader in topic coverage, such as a review article, web source that presents a given topic, a book chapter etc - anything that helps you generalize, give overview. 
Example: 
HW1: You made an oral presentation about a new METHOD FOR NUCLEIC ACID DELIVERY - a novel type of biopolymer that efficiently transfects cells. 
HW3: Now, because this is a subtopic under a general application of GENE THERAPY, you could make a written report and describe other transfection methods and give an overview about the current state-of-the-art of gene therapy. Alternatively, you could prepare a report of slightly less narrow topic - different methods for transfection, along with their strengths and weaknesses, some possible future directions etc. 
A good report has details, but also presents an overview of the topic. 
Present your report (oral in the class AND written to Kaido Kurrikoff)
If you are doing a group work, distribute tasks between yourselves and adhere to time schedule where you'll meet, discuss, share the progress. Group work can help to more easily cover larger topics, but extra effort must be spent on synchronization.

resources.mandatory_materials:
There is no universal book (yet). The field is not mature enough that there is no single book or source of information that can act like a textbook for students.
I have made copies from some parts of a textbook "Handbook of clinical Nanomedicine" (Raj Bawa) for your reference (not for public distribution!), but these serve as general source material and the chapters do not strictly follow the course topics.
